eventType.name: Academic Departments & Programs
eventType.description: Get to know more about some academic departments & programs at Yale through these live events.

eventData.headline: Molecular Biophysics & Biochemistry
eventData.description:
The undergraduate programs offered by the department of Molecular Biophysics & Biochemistry (MB&B) are for students interested in not only what life is, but also in how it works. We seek to understand life at a mechanistic level by studying how the extraordinarily complex molecules found in living organisms create structures, carry out chemistry, and store and utilize information to generate the remarkable properties of living organisms. Biochemistry and biophysics are rapidly advancing areas of science that underlie the current dramatic progress in medicine.  

Our undergraduate degree programs are well suited for students planning to attend medical school or graduate studies in biochemistry, molecular biology, genetics, genomics, or biophysics. The MB&B major differs from the programs offered by the Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology (MCDB) department in that MB&B places its central focus on studying biology using the tools of chemistry, physics, and biochemistry. MB&B students thus carry out more in-depth coursework in these areas, and typically take less coursework in other areas such as organismal biology, cell biology, and genetics.

MB&B has found that undergraduates have a lot of questions about what is involved in pursuing the MB&B major.  To address this, we have put together some “quick facts” about MB&B.   The intent is to answer some commonly asked questions and provide central features each potential major will want to know.    MBB Quick Facts

https://yale.zoom.us/j/94007000957

eventData.headline: Yale College Equestrian Team
eventData.description:
Equestrian club team for Yale undergraduates. Provide lessons and instructions for every level of equestrian from beginner to advanced. Competitive team that attends competitions throughout the year.

Join to ask questions and learn about the team!

eventType.name: Student Groups
eventType.description: Opportunities to get to know student groups and resources on campus!

eventData.headline: Yale Student Energy Association
eventData.description:
The Yale Student Energy Association is Yale’s premier student-run energy club. The club addresses issues ranging from new solar technologies to carbon capture and sequestration to nuclear fusion, and provides students with an opportunity to learn from the very best in the field through the Lecture series and first-hand opportunities to lead an initiative that would impact Yale’s community.

Are you interested in learning more about where your laptop’s power comes from? Do you have an idea that could change the way we perceive energy and use it more sustainably? Do you want to create an immediate impact at Yale and improve the relationship and awareness of energy issues? If your answer to any of these questions is “yes”, then join us for a discussion of the student aspects of Energy@Yale.

The sessions will include explanations about Yale Student Energy Association, Yale’s premier undergraduate energy group, the Yale Energy Alliance, the umbrella group for everything energy, and the Student Energy Consortium, the national intercollegiate network for energy activities. We will also be happy to entertain questions about activities/events, academic pathways, and career pathways in energy from a student’s point of view. Can’t wait to see you all!

eventType.description: Opportunities to get to know student groups and resources on campus!

eventData.headline: Yale Effective Altruism
eventData.description:
At Yale Effective Altruism, our mission is to answer one question: how can we do the most good with our resources? We are driven to solve the largest problems that humanity faces today—whether it be global health, extreme poverty, animal welfare, engineered pandemics, AI Risk, nuclear security, climate change, or other existential and global catastrophic risks—through research, public policy, ethics, charity entrepreneurship, philanthropy, direct work, and the many other resources, opportunities and privileges at our disposal.

In joining us, you won’t just enjoy deep and lasting conversations, but a global community stretching across all disciplines, such as philosophy, psychology, political science, computer science, history, economics, and more, working together to identify and solve the most impactful cause areas of today.

We host speaker events, dinners with prominent professors, weekly discussion groups, and an immersive ‘Fellowship Program’, which is aimed at helping our members build their plans for how they will help improve the world.

If any of the above interests you, consider stopping by!

WELCOME TO YALE! We’re interested in helping you find summer opportunities and join the Yale Effective Altruism community. Come to learn about our summer fellowship program, open this summer to all prefrosh!

Read more about our fellowship program here: https://www.yaleea.com/fellowship
Schedule for 1 on 1’s with YEA members here: https://airtable.com/shrOLV2b11wq48gd0

eventData.headline: Yale Undergraduate Legal Aid Association
eventData.description:
We are a Dwight Hall member organization dedicated to social justice and the proud winner of the title of Dwight Hall Member Group of the 2017-2018 Academic Year. In our current form as YULAA, we provide an outlet to hundreds of service-minded Yale students who are interested in engaging with the legal system as undergraduate before they pursue advanced degrees or enter the workforce. Our diverse local service opportunities allow for students to work on issues that interest them, whether that be immigration, police accountability, or re-entry of formerly incarcerated individuals. Currently, we have roughly 150 Yale students actively volunteering on project sites.

Our goal is also to serve as an important resource for the New Haven community. Legal service organizations are often understaffed for the amount of work they have. YULAA volunteers do actual legal work, whether that be translating legal documents, writing affidavits for asylum-seekers, or assisting with pardon applications.

Our goal is also to serve as an important resource for the New Haven community. Legal service organizations are often understaffed for the amount of work they have. YULAA volunteers do actual legal work, whether that be translating legal documents, writing affidavits for asylum-seekers, or assisting with pardon applications.

Come talk to board and learn more about YULAA/sign up for our newsletter!!

eventData.headline: Air Force ROTC
eventData.description:
The Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps (AFROTC) at Yale is a four-year program that develops cadets into leaders of character and prepares them for commissioning into the Air Force and the Space Force. Along with completing their degree requirements, cadets develop the physical capabilities and leadership competencies required to serve in a variety of career fields upon graduation. Learn more during this session!

https://yale.zoom.us/j/94556341059

eventType.description: Opportunities to get to know student groups and resources on campus!

eventData.headline: Yale Anti-Gravity Society
eventData.description:
The Yale Anti-Gravity Society aims to bring together jugglers and people with other circus-related talents of all skill levels so that we may learn from one another and grow as entertainers and performers. Juggling along with other circus arts is intrinsically a group activity, and we aim to create a supportive space where anyone with any interest in such activities can share their passion with other like-minded individuals and possibly collaborate on performances.

Come hang out with YAGS and learn about the wonders of juggling at Yale!

eventData.headline: Yale Badminton Team
eventData.description:
We are the official Yale Badminton Team, a club team comprised of undergraduate and graduate players that compete at home and away meets every year.

This zoom event is a chance for prospective students to meet and get to know the current members of the team, as well as have a chance to have any questions answered.

eventType.description: Opportunities to get to know student groups and resources on campus!

eventData.headline: Code Haven
eventData.description:
Code Haven is an undergraduate student organization at Yale University dedicated to introducing young students to computer science! Every week, Code Haven mentors teach computing lessons at several schools in the New Haven district, engaging the students with online lessons, group activities, and class-wide demonstrations. Mentors are Yale undergrads who hail from a variety of backgrounds and possess myriad academic and extracurricular interests, but they all share a passion for making education more readily accessible and inclusive!

Code Haven will be hosting an informational session on April 16th and April 30th! Prospective Yalies will get a chance to hear from current mentors and board members about the Code Haven experience, outreach and volunteering opportunities in New Haven, CS at Yale, and more! Most importantly, the info session will serve as a chance for prefrosh to meet current Yale students in a casual setting. Everyone, regardless of their experience in CS, is welcome to attend!
